content.description: Steep, blocky start leads to sharp small holds.  The route has a big pocket just below the fourth bolt.  Getting above the bolt requires a power move with high feet.  It's a great one, though, and is the best part of the route.
content.location: From the parking lot, follow the trail down with the rock face to the right.  First route on the West side of the formation.

content.description:
Stemming corner past 3 bolts to anchors.  Awkward line, jumped on it thinking it would be fun for the beginner I was with to try...not the case.

The climb doesn't have a good flow at all,

but thats my opinion so check it out if you want.
content.location: Route is found in corner just right of angering the cheese gods.

content.description: Overhanging shelves to sharp arete. Hard pockets.

From

Goss guidebook this climb is rated 11a: "Awkward moves to attain a ledge, then pockets."

The “awkward moves” involve a heel hook to a double knee bar up to an awesome left pocket, followed by a second crux higher up to get over the bulge, a dynamic throw to an undercling. I thought this was a super fun route, similar to Funky Boss and maybe only slightly harder.

20 feet of sport climbing protected with 3 bolts, to an awesome trad crack that is safe and protects with great gear.

From Darren here is the beta: while you are standing on the rest ledge, you get to protect right off the bat. Reach high, place a large nut (you can use an #8 #9 or #10 from any company) right above were the crack goes steep to vertical...clip a quickdraw to it, yank it hard to set it, because the next moves are tricky and pumpy, and remember that nut is what you are most likely to fall on, but that's what nuts are for!...Do a few moves, reach up and set that large 6" green cam you've seen in those offwith movies, in the middle of the steep climbing. If you forgot yours, do a few more moves to the dead vertical terrain were you can place a silver 1.5", green 1.75 (my choice), or a red 2" cam. The rest is really fun climbing...clip the anchors. Congrats! You just redpointed "Overlooked 10c."
content.protection:
3 bolts to 20ish feet of trad crack, to quicklink anchors.

1- #8 #9 or #10 nut,

1- large 6" green cam

1- silver 1.5", green 1.75 (my choice), or a red 2" cam.
content.location: Immediately right of Pumping Out of Gas.

content.description: Mix of Trad and Sport, or a runout to your first bolt. Use medium gear in crack and stem up past the two bolts. Keep right at the start for an easier option.
content.protection: Medium gear or just two bolts to 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: In between Starting Block and the Slums detached cliff.

content.description: Ledgey chossy bottom into clean pocket face. Possible to toprope (anchor is right below the many highline bolts).
Fun route on small crimps and finger pockets.  Cruxes come after clipping the first bolt and at the fourth.  Go as fast as you can, the rock is sharp.
content.location: After descending the right side of the Starting block, pass Dr. Diaper.  The face to the right (east-facing) has three routes.  HH is in the center.

climbs.name: Funky Boss
climbs.fa: Todd Goss (could be wrong, but it's in his guidebook).

content.description: Crux is pulling the overhang in the center. Looks full of pockets, but are deceitfully slopers...
content.location: Looking at the staring block (Heimie, Howard Hughes, Blue Suede Shoes, etc) it's around the corner to the right, on the face. There's a subtle route to its left and another face route to its right.

content.description: A finger crack that widens at the top to allow one or two nice hand jams. Often TRed, this requires leaning further over the edge than is comfortable to reach the chains.
content.protection: A single set of nuts  and accompanying slings should suffice to get to chain anchors.
content.location: Dr. Diaper is the first route and obvious crack to the left after descending the trail to the right of the Starting Block formation.

content.description: Strange fracture/crack that gets you to a bolted anchor.
content.protection: Small pieces up high and maybe some medium pieces down low.
content.location: Left of As the song and Dance Begins and right of What's my line.

climbs.name: As the Song and Dance Begins

content.description: Nice, short route and a great introduction to the type of climbing in the area.  Starts with good pockets and ledges and comes to a small bulge at the second bolt (crux).  The climb continues easily past a third bolt to the anchors.
content.protection: 3 bolts to bolt anchors (widely spaced anchors...long slings suggested)
content.location: From the parking lot, follow the trail to the formation, then follow the formation to the steep slope to the right.  At the bottom of the slope with the rock to the right, it's the first route.  It's about a 3 minute walk.

content.description: This is a fun route that starts with some great pockets and ledges.  These get thin near the third bolt (crux), but long arms can find good holds to work over the bulge.  There seems to be quite a bit of matching in small holds on this one.
content.location: Route starts to the left of As the Song and Dance Begins.  From ATSADB, pass the obvious crack and corner to the face route that begins on a big ledge.

content.description: Great route on vertical face using mostly two finger pockets the whole way up.  Sustained pocket climbing leads to a crux near the top just before the fourth bolt.
content.protection: follows 4 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Southern most route on the vertical streaked wall just right of Dr. Diaper.

content.description: Short but sustained pocket pulling along a face/arête with spectacular views of the valley below. Quality.
content.protection: 5 bolts to 2 single rap ring anchors
content.location:
Between "No Rhyme or Reason" and

Howard Hughes

.
